sentences.english: Before long, his widow and children were in rags, begging on the streets.
sentences.chinese: 不久，他的妻兒們就衣裳襤褸，要到街上要飯了。

sentences.english: He has a wife and family depending on him.
Is Bill fully morally responsible for killing his wife and children?
sentences.chinese: 比爾是否對殺死他的妻兒負有道德責任？

sentences.english: Li and his family live in Jingyuan, in the centre of Gansu.
sentences.chinese: 李壯和妻兒一家四口住在甘肅省中部的靖遠縣。

sentences.english: A young Tibetan took his mother to see the doctors in the town, and his wife and kid were seeing them off.
sentences.chinese: 年輕的藏民帶老母親去縣城看病，妻兒在車下相送。

sentences.english: Reach for wife and children rescued, agreed to sell the officer in the front of vibration of witness.
sentences.chinese: 致遠因妻兒被救，答應振鋒爲賣官的事做證。

sentences.english: When Mr Smith died his wife and childern were left destitute .
sentences.chinese: 史密斯先生死後他的妻兒變得一貧如洗。

sentences.english: His wife and children parents together the happiness of a family union, and friend wine lotus word poetry.
sentences.chinese: 與妻兒父母齊天倫之樂，與朋友友把酒忘憂言詩詞。

sentences.english: It had been more than a year since he'd seen them.
sentences.chinese: 除了看看照片，約翰森已經一年多沒有見到過妻兒了。

sentences.english: He abandoned his wife and children for another woman.
I'm sure that I shall be well able to provide for my wife and family.
sentences.chinese: 我確信我將完全能養活我的妻兒老小。

sentences.english: The man shamelessly abandoned his wife and child for another woman.
sentences.chinese: 那個男人無恥地拋棄了妻兒，另覓新歡。

sentences.english: All the monkeys in his band were his own wives and children.
sentences.chinese: 猴羣中所有的猴子都是他的妻兒。

sentences.english: Many sailors drink their wives and children out of doors.
sentences.chinese: 溺於酒以致妻兒一貧如洗。

sentences.english: But a year ago, he returned, with his wife and children, to Long Island.
sentences.chinese: 但一年前，他和妻兒回到了紐約長島。

sentences.english: Scot lives with his wife and three children, two dogs and some chooks in the bush in Eastern Victoria.
sentences.chinese: 他和妻兒及寵物住在維多利亞東部的叢林。

definition: to leave one's native place, esp. against one's will (idiom)
elder brother/term of respect for a man of about the same age
to leave one's homeplace (to find work, flee disaster etc)
deeply worried and sick at heart (idiom)
to be without a fixed residence (idiom)
unable to move freely/difficult to get about
to look up and see no-one familiar (idiom); not having anyone to rely on/without a friend in the world
